documentType: Bureau of Prisons incident report and related records
summary: This document is a Bureau of Prisons Form 583 Report of Incident regarding an apparent suicide attempt by inmate Jeffrey Epstein on July 23, 2019, at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York. It includes the incident report, a daily staff roster, a health services clinical encounter, and an administrative detention order. The report details Epstein being found in his cell with a rope around his neck and subsequent placement on suicide watch. This document is a collection of email correspondence from July-August 2019 concerning the incarceration and death of Jeffrey Epstein at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York. It includes internal BOP communications, messages from Epstein's attorneys, and discussions about his medical status, cell assignments, and the investigation into his death. This document is a collection of email correspondence from July to November 2019, primarily between Bureau of Prisons (BOP) staff, attorneys, and law enforcement regarding Jeffrey Epstein's incarceration at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York. It details his status changes (suicide watch, psychological observation), an alleged cellmate attack, the provision of a CPAP machine, and internal investigations following his death. It also includes a paralegal's application inquiry and a press inquiry about another inmate. This document is a collection of email chains from July-August 2019 concerning the detention and death of Jeffrey Epstein at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York. It includes internal BOP communications, attorney complaints about Epstein's conditions, media inquiries, and the initiation of a litigation hold following his death. This document is a collection of email correspondence primarily from August 10-11, 2019, concerning the death of Jeffrey Epstein at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC). It includes a formal request from Epstein's family attorney, Martin Weinberg, for the preservation and production of all evidence related to Epstein's detention and death, as well as earlier internal MCC emails discussing his attempted suicide on July 23, 2019, and his conditions of confinement. This document is a collection of internal Bureau of Prisons emails from July to November 2019 concerning the detention, treatment, and death of Jeffrey Epstein at the Metropolitan Correctional Center in New York. It includes discussions about his mental health status, cell assignments, attorney complaints about his conditions, the official notification of his death, and subsequent requests for investigation materials and preservation of evidence. This document contains email correspondence from August 2019 regarding a Touhy request from Jeffrey Epstein's attorneys for his medical/psychological records while he was incarcerated. It also includes a separate email from a paralegal applicant, Samanta Honigman, inquiring about her application to work with Epstein. The emails show coordination between the U.S. Attorney's Office, the correctional center, and Epstein's legal team.

events.title: Epstein Apparent Suicide Attempt
events.description: At approximately 1:27 AM, inmate Jeffrey Epstein was found in his cell (Z05-124LAD) in the Special Housing Unit (SHU) at MCC New York. He was lying on the floor with a rope around his neck, breathing heavily and snoring. He was placed in hand restraints, taken to the HA-Unit, dressed in a suicide smock, and placed on suicide watch.

events.title: Medical Examination of Epstein
events.description: At 06:20, MLP examined Epstein. Epstein was ambulatory, oriented, and smiling. He alleged he did not know what happened and could not explain the marks on his neck. The exam revealed a circular line of erythema at the base of his neck and a small erythema on his left knee.

events.title: Epstein Placed in Administrative Detention
events.description: An administrative detention order was issued for Jeffrey Epstein, citing 'PENDING CLASSIFICATION' as the reason, indicating his continued presence in general population posed a threat.

events.title: Email Discussion on Guard Checks
events.description: Email correspondence references a Reuters/Breitbart report alleging prison guards skipped mandatory checks before Epstein's death, prompting a request for an update call.

events.title: Epstein Found Injured in Cell
events.description: At approximately 1:27 a.m., staff found inmate Jeffrey Epstein lying on the floor in a fetal position in the SHU with red marks on his neck. He was placed on suicide watch.

events.title: Epstein Stepped Down to Psychological Observation
events.description: Epstein was removed from Suicide Watch and stepped down to Psychological Observation status. He was given a pending incident report for Self-Mutilation (Code 228).

events.title: Epstein Released from Psychological Observation
events.description: According to a Psych Ops log book, Epstein was released from Psychological Observation on July 30, 2019, and had an attorney visit starting at 8:20 a.m.

events.title: Epstein's Death
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was reported to have been taken by ambulance to the hospital from another apparent suicide attempt and was later pronounced dead. The BOP issued a press release.

events.title: Internal Discussion on Prison Guard Checks
events.description: Internal email discussion referencing a Reuters/Breitbart report that prison guards skipped mandatory checks before Epstein's death, expressing disbelief and planning a call to discuss.

events.title: Epstein alleges cellmate attack, placed on suicide watch
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein alleged that a cellmate attempted to kill him and that he had informed his attorney. As a precaution, he was placed on suicide watch, though BOP staff suspected manipulation to get a single cell.

events.title: Epstein stepped down to Psychological Observation
events.description: Epstein was removed from Suicide Watch and stepped down to Psychological Observation status. He was assessed in Health Services and then taken to meet with his attorney.

events.title: Press inquiry about Tartaglione and Epstein
events.description: Journalist M. Connor contacted attorney Bruce Barket to confirm an NBC story that his client, Nicholas Tartaglione, was questioned about a possible attack on Jeffrey Epstein at the MCC.

events.title: Epstein's CPAP machine and return to SHU
events.description: Epstein received his CPAP machine. He requested to stay in the medical area but was told he would return to the SHU with a cellmate the next day, as there were no mental health issues precluding it.

events.title: FDLE assumes lead in Florida review
events.description: Sheriff Rick Bradshaw reported that the Florida Department of Law Enforcement (FDLE) had assumed the lead role in the administrative review/criminal investigation of Epstein's time under Palm Beach County Sheriff's Office control.

events.title: Scheduled Psychological Reconstruction meeting

events.title: USMS requests Epstein death investigation reports
events.description: The U.S. Marshals Service Prisoner Operations Division requested any reports prepared in the investigation surrounding the death of Jeffrey Epstein from the BOP.

events.title: Epstein Found with Neck Marks
events.description: At 1:27 AM, staff found Epstein lying on the floor in a fetal position in the SHU with red marks on his neck. He was medically assessed, placed on suicide watch, and the incident was investigated as self-mutilation.

events.title: Epstein Removed from Suicide Watch
events.description: Epstein was removed from Suicide Watch and stepped down to Psychological Observation. He was escorted for a follow-up assessment and then to meet with his attorney.

events.title: Death of Jeffrey Epstein
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein died in his cell at the MCC. The event triggered a litigation hold and a formal request from his family's attorney to preserve all related evidence.

events.title: Litigation Hold Initiated
events.description: The U.S. Attorney's Office for the SDNY initiated a litigation hold relating to Epstein's death, covering records pertaining to his investigation and prosecution.

events.title: Epstein Denied Bail
events.description: Epstein returned to MCC from court without incident after being denied bail.

events.title: Epstein's Attempted Suicide/Incident
events.description: Epstein was found in his SHU cell with red marks on his neck and was placed on suicide watch. The incident was investigated as an attempted suicide.

events.title: Family's Evidence Preservation Request

keyFacts: On July 23, 2019, at approximately 1:27 AM, Jeffrey Epstein was found in his SHU cell with a rope around his neck in an apparent suicide attempt.
The incident report notes that when staff made eye contact with Epstein as he was being placed on a stretcher, he would 'hurriedly shut his eyes.'
The medical examination found a circular line of erythema (redness) at the base of Epstein's neck, consistent with a rope, but Epstein claimed he did not know how it happened.
Epstein had been placed in Administrative Detention on July 10, 2019, pending classification.
Subsequent email correspondence on August 11, 2019, references a news report alleging prison guards skipped mandatory checks prior to Epstein's death.
On July 23, 2019, Jeffrey Epstein was found in his SHU cell with red marks on his neck and was placed on suicide watch, later stepped down to Psychological Observation.
Epstein's attorneys, including Jonathan Savella, were actively trying to secure a CPAP machine for him and set up his inmate telephone account in late July/early August 2019.
Epstein died on August 10, 2019, with initial reports indicating another apparent suicide attempt; the BOP was criticized for releasing information to the press before informing prosecutors.
Internal emails show concern and investigation into a media leak that inmate Nicholas Tartaglione was questioned about a possible attack on Epstein.
